title: China just showed off a new missile that could slip past US defenses at more than five times the speed of sound
text:
China unveiled its new DF-17 missile, a weapon armed with a hypersonic glide vehicle designed to penetrate enemy air defenses at speeds in excess of Mach 5, during its National Day parade Tuesday.

"It definitely ratchets things up in terms of the threat level to US forces in the region," a missile expert told Business Insider.

The US is currently working to develop a ground-launched hypersonic missile, but it is not expected to be able to field them until 2023.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

The People's Republic of China celebrated the 70th anniversary of its founding with a show of force that included a new hypersonic missile built to beat enemy air defenses at more than five times the speed of sound.

The Chinese DF-17 is a missile equipped with a hypersonic glide vehicle (HGV), and it was unveiled for the first time during a military parade in Beijing Tuesday.

Tuesday's display appears to be the first time a country has presented a purportedly working hypersonic missile — an aerodynamic warhead that, unlike a ballistic missile, flies inside the atmosphere along unpredictable flight paths at high speeds, causing all kinds of trouble for most existing air- and missile-defense systems.

The weapon, which is set to be incorporated into the People's Liberation Army Rocket Force possibly as early as 2020, was first tested in November 2017, The Diplomat reported at the time, citing US government sources.

One source told The Diplomat's Ankit Panda that the initial test of the DF-17 marked "the first HGV test in the world using a system intended to be fielded operationally" rather than a test bed system.

Earlier this year, the Defense Intelligence Agency assessed that China is "on the verge of fielding some of the most modern weapon systems in the world."

The eventual fielding of the DF-17 will represent a major step forward for the People's Liberation Army, as well as a clear escalation of the threat posed by China's armed forces.

"It definitely ratchets things up in terms of the threat level to US forces in the region," Ian Williams, the deputy director of the Missile Defense Project at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, told Business Insider.

"It's pretty clear what China wants to do with them," he further explained. "They want to be able to threaten US forward-deployed forces so that they can prevail in a very quick, sharp conflict if that happens."

Military vehicles carrying DF-17 hypersonic missiles travel past Tiananmen Square during a military parade for the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, in Beijing, October 1, 2019. REUTERS/Jason Lee

The US is not only re-evaluating its approach to missile defense, as the Pentagon's Missile Defense Review explains, but the US military is also striving to develop hypersonic systems of its own.

The US appears to be trying to catch up rather than lead the way on this new technology.

"In the last year, China has tested more hypersonics weapons than we have in a decade," Michael Griffin, undersecretary of defense for research and engineering, said at the end of 2018. "We've got to fix that."

Army Lt. Gen. Neil Thurgood, the director of the Army's new Rapid Capabilities and Critical Technologies Office (RCCTO) charged with the development of a hypersonic glide vehicle for ground-launched hypersonic weapons, said in May that his office is in a "full-out sprint" to develop this technology.

Thurgood's announcement followed a decision in March by the secretary and chief of staff of the Army to accelerate the delivery of a prototype ground-launched hypersonic weapon.

"With near-peer competitors developing their own hypersonic capabilities, the Army plans to counter them with about $1.2 billion on experimental prototyping through fiscal 2024," the Army said two months later.

Two related contracts were awarded to Dynetics and Lockheed Martin for $351.6 million and $347 million, respectively, in August.

But while the US is working hard to develop hypersonic weapons, the earliest expected delivery date is fiscal year 2023, likely well behind some of America's near-peer adversaries.
description: A hypersonic missile releases an aerodynamic warhead that can maneuver along unusual and unpredictable flight paths at high speeds to skirt defenses.
